Dev Log

[!tldr] Summary Maxime Vaillancourt wrote a tutorial for setting up a Jekyll project with their template: Max Vaillancourt‚Äôs Jekyll Template Tutorial. This is my journey following along with the tutorial.

Part 1 - Struggle with Ruby

Let‚Äôs begin! Step 0: ! [[ Max Vaillancourt‚Äôs Jekyll Template Tutorial#0 Set up prerequisites ]]

  • This led me down a frustrating path of installing [[ Ruby ]], which apparently comes installed on MacOS by default, but you can‚Äôt really use that version to develop without a bunch of sudo commands that you probably should avoid.
  • Tried to install Ruby with rbenv, and had no fun at all‚Ä¶
  • Double-backed, successfully installed [[ Ruby enVironment Manager|RVM ]] instead!
    • This finally made me able let me switch which ruby to output: 
      #which ruby
/Users/michael/.rvm/rubies/ruby-3.0.0/bin/ruby
  • Ok so now my version of Ruby is the correct one‚Ä¶ üòÑ

Part 2 - Local Development

[[ Max Vaillancourt‚Äôs Jekyll Template Tutorial#1 Create a fork of the template repository|Step 1 ]] and [[ Max Vaillancourt‚Äôs Jekyll Template Tutorial#2 Clone your repository locally|Step 2 ]] had no problems!

And then‚Ä¶

! [[ Max Vaillancourt‚Äôs Jekyll Template Tutorial#3 Test out the site locally ]]

But when I tried to bundle in my new project directory, I received an errored output. See ‚û°Ô∏è to direct your attention

In Gemfile:

  • Ok so we know there is an error installing the eventmachine 1.2.7 package, and it might have something to do with SSL.
  • It says try gem install eventmachine -v '1.2.7' --source 'https://rubygems.org/'
    • No luck, similar (if not exact same) issue
  • ~scours the internet~
  • GitHub user, ITJamie, with this amazing comment on a GitHub Issue

[!quote] if on an m1 mac use¬†-- --with-openssl-dir=/opt/homebrew/opt/openssl@1.1¬†instead

And so I do:

[!tip] Boom.

gem install eventmachine -- --with-openssl-dir=/opt/homebrew/opt/openssl@1.1¬† -v '1.2.7' --source 'https://rubygems.org/'

Success! üòÑ bundle works successfully and so does bundle exec jekyll serve

Part 3 - Hosting

  • Kinda skipping over this a bit‚Ä¶
    • Connect GitHub to [[ Netlify ]]
    • Connect Google Domains to Netlify
      • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cDDr-NoI5fo
  • Configured the DNS settings as Netlify instructed

Part 4 - Adapting to my setup > notes locations

Given that I‚Äôve already configured my personal notes in such a way that may not be compatible with this system, I need to solve two things:

  1. Can I have my notes folder live in a different location?
  2. Can I selectively publish notes?

We‚Äôll get to the second point later; let‚Äôs address the first point now.

The Jekyll template requests that you place your notes in a folder named _notes. I learned later that this is known as a collection. But I already have a notes folder (path) that I‚Äôd like to keep which enables me to access my notes from multiple devices.

Enter symlinks ‚Üí With the following code I was able to create a symlink to the true notes directory inside of the project folder. Then I simply renamed the symlink to _notes. Now the contents of the _notes folder are actually located in a different location:

# do this, then rename the shortcut to _notes
ln -s /path/to/preferred/notes/location /path/to/project/folder

Part 5 - Adapting to my setup > selectively publishing

This part caused me some pain.

5.1 | First Attempt - YAML Front Matter alone

[!warning] This part did not work out in the final solution, but feel free to read for context!

Since I use my notes for everything in my life, there‚Äôs likely some content I don‚Äôt want to share; simple to-do lists, personally identifiable information (PII), etc. I realize that I could split my notes into two folders, one for public and one for private, but I like to keep them together for the benefit of linking everything and for the Obsidian graph feature.

Turns out the [[ YAML front matter ]] on each note, plus the config.yaml file gives us all of the power we need to set rules about what gets published, and therefore, built for the site. I needed to make two edits to the config file to ensure the best experience:

exclude: [
'_includes/notes_graph.json',
'_notes/*.pdf',
'_notes/**/*.pdf',
'_notes/*.png',
'_notes/**/*.png',
'_notes/.obsidian/*' # This was a result of the symlink
]

defaults:
	- scope
		path: "_notes/**/*.md"
	values:
		layout: "note"
		published: false
  • For the exclude variable, I don‚Äôt want to build any files that aren‚Äôt .md‚Ä¶ for now. Not sure how this will work for notes with embedded images. More on this later?
  • I added a published: false to ensure that any notes that might be lacking front matter don‚Äôt get published.

5.2 | Second Attempt - Building locally instead of in Netlify

Just when I thought I had figured out my perfect system, I realized I still had a problem.

The published: false front matter is helpful for ignoring notes at build time, but the current CI/CD workflow requires that you are committing even those private notes to the git history. This means the contents of the notes would be pushed to GitHub, and therefore made public.

Of course we could just make the repository private, but I don‚Äôt like that I‚Äôm being forced to do so. Additionally, the confidentiality of my private notes would come at the expense of cutting myself off from other developers who may be interested in this digital garden work.

After giving it some more thought, I‚Äôve come up with a solution for the moment, although I‚Äôm not certain it will remain this way for long. Instead of committing the notes and building with Netlify, we‚Äôll build locally and post the built site. This will make sure that only publishable content

5.2.1 Switch up the commit

First, I need to ensure that my _notes are never committed to the git history. This should be easy adding the following to the .gitignore:

# Don't commit notes to the git history
_notes/

Instead we‚Äôll make sure we‚Äôre committing the _site folder contents, so we‚Äôll need to remove the statement which tells git to ignore it. The final .gitignore file looks like this:

# Don't commit notes to the git history
_notes/

# Sass cache
.sass-cache/

# Jekyll cache & metadata
.jekyll-cache/
.jekyll-metadata

# Notes graph metadata
_includes/notes_graph.json

# Obsidian config
.obsidian/
5.2.2 Make sure Netlify knows!

Remove the command = "jekyll build --trace" statement from the netlify.toml file and you get:

[build]
  publish = "_site"

Ok! Nearly there‚Ä¶

Part 6 - The new build & deploy process

With our new setup, once we‚Äôve update our notes & content, we‚Äôll need to build, commit, and then push to GitHub for the changes to be deployed. In short,

git add . # Add modified files to staging area
git commit -m "Updated content" # Explain
git push  # Send it up!

Netlify will detect the commit and deploy the new site!

flowchart BT

/_notes -.symlink.-> /path/to/preferred/notes/location 
/_notes -.ignored during commit.-> .gitignore
/_notes --> build
build --> /_site --> commited --> pushed --> Netlify
